title: How UPS uniforms have changed over the past 100 years
text:
United Parcel Service Inc. said Wednesday that its iconic “Browns” uniform was getting a makeover to a more contemporary look.

No, the color isn’t changing, but drivers will be sporting a new pullover polo-style shirt made of a micro-pique fabric that wicks moisture away and improves breathability, and is more comfortable to wear.

The uniforms will still include shorts, which were first introduced in 1991, but the pants will now be made with a stretch twill, a lower waist and more modern fit.

“The updates are designed to improve driver comfort, safety and performance,” UPS said in a statement. “UPS drivers are often referred to as industrial athletes, so many of the changes to the uniform include using performance fabrics with improved stretch for better range of motion,” the statement read.

UPS UPS, -1.10% said it takes nearly four million yards of brown cloth and two million yards of brown thread for the 375,000 hats, 405,000 shirts, 375,000 pants and 290,000 pairs of shorts it issues its drivers.

And drivers don’t get just one uniform they have to wear over and over.

“Drivers are issued multiple pairs of pants, shorts and shirts and in many locations UPS provides laundering services,” spokesperson Dan McMackin wrote in an email to MarketWatch.

McMackin said the company’s uniform suppliers are Twin Hill, a subsidiary of Tailored Brands Inc.’s TLRD, +0.00% Mens Wearhouse Inc., and food, facilities management and uniforms services company Aramark ARMK, -0.21%. Tailored Brand shares fell 0.9% in afternoon trading Wednesday and Aramark’s stock slipped 0.3%.

UPS’s stock, which fell 2.1% in afternoon trading in the wake or rival FedEx Corp.’s FDX, -12.92% disappointing quarterly results and outlook, has now gained 23% year to date, while the Dow Jones Transportation Average DJT, -1.21% has advanced 14% and the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, +0.13% has climbed 15%.

The latest change adds to the many uniforms introduced over the past century.
